user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleUnload_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleUnload_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32                             status = OS_ERROR;
    OS_impl_module_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_module_table, *token);

    /*
    ** Attempt to close/unload the module
    */
    dlerror();
    if (dlclose(impl->dl_handle) == 0)
    {
        impl->dl_handle = NULL;
        status          = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error unloading shared library: %s\n", dlerror());
    }

    return status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ModuleUnload_Impl:
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
int32 OS_ModuleUnload(osal_id_t module_id)
{
    OS_module_internal_record_t *module;
    int32                        return_code;
    OS_object_token_t            token;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, module_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        module = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_module_table, token);

        /*
         * Only call the implementation if the file was actually loaded.
         * If this is a static module, then this is just a placeholder and
         * it means there was no file actually loaded.
         */
        if (module->module_type == OS_MODULE_TYPE_DYNAMIC)
        {
            return_code = OS_ModuleUnload_Impl(&token);
        }

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
The selected fragments are the call site that invokes the implementation (OS_ModuleUnload_Impl), the implementation function itself, the call that obtains the object token, and the call that finalizes the delete. These are the places where an indirect recursion cycle involving unload/finalize could originate or re-enter and thus must be investigated.

Other fragments in the provided code do not need investigation for Rule 17.2: the inline accessor OS_ObjectIndexFromToken simply returns a field and makes no function calls; the macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET merely indexes the table using that accessor; OS_DEBUG is defined empty; dlerror() is used only to clear/obtain dynamic loader error strings and does not itself call back into the OS object-management functions shown; the direct use of impl->dl_handle is a simple pointer access. None of these contain function calls that would create a direct or indirect call cycle with the module-unload path, so they do not warrant further investigation for recursion under Rule 17.2.
